# Introduction {-}

This document is part of teaching materials created for the CarpentryCon conference. The purpose is to practise R Markdown, including basic features such as Markdown markup and code chunks, along with more special features such as [cross-references for figures and tables](https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown-cookbook/cross-ref.html).

The conference was originally going to take place in Madison, so let's look at some [open data from the City of Madison](https://data-cityofmadison.opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/parks?geometry=-89.997%2C43.007%2C-88.679%2C43.183).

Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum. Figure \@ref(fig:count) shows the counts of various types of parks in Madison.

```{r count, fig.cap='Types of parks in Madison.'}

dat = read.csv('https://opendata.arcgis.com/datasets/9e00ff81868e49b7ba65d4e628b9e14f_6.csv')

dat = 
  dat %>%
  group_by(Type) %>%
  mutate(count_types = n())

# Showing the code because echo=TRUE 
ggplotly(
  ggplot(dat, aes(x=reorder(Type, count_types),
                  text = paste('Count =', count_types), 
                  y=count_types)) + 
    theme(axis.title.y=element_blank()) + stat_identity(geom='bar') + 
    labs(x='Type', y='Count') + coord_flip(), tooltip = 'text'
)

```

Table \@ref(tab:largest-parks) shows the twenty largest parks types, along with their type and acreage.

The code doesn't below because `echo = FALSE`. 

```{r largest-parks, echo=FALSE}

kable(
  dat %>%
    summarize(Name = Park_Name, Type, Acreage) %>%
    arrange(-Acreage, Name, Type) %>%
    select(Name, Type, Acreage) %>%
    head(20),
  caption='Types of parks and names in Madison.'
)

```


We could choose to display the code for the table at this point, which can be done using the parameters `ref.label='largest-parks', echo = T, eval = F` in the chunk options ([Xie, Dervieux, &  Riederer, 2020](https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown-cookbook/reuse-chunks.html)).

```{r ref.label = 'largest-parks', echo = T, eval = F}
```
